repnme.cdata!: Republic of Yemen - Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Technical Assistance Project in Yemen.
            The objective of the project was to improve staff capability
            in key departments of the Central Planning Organization
            (CPO) and to establish procedures that would strengthen
            CPO's operations and its working relationship with
            other ministries and agencies.  Bank's performance was
            satisfactory. Borrower's performance was satisfactory.
            The key lessons learned were as follows: (i) during project
            implementation, grants could become available and displace
            International Development Association (IDA) resource
            earmarked for specific project activities; (ii)
            institutional development components of Technical Assistance
            (TA) projects should be contingent upon government agreement
            on a detailed institutional plan for the ministry or agency
            concerned; (iii) in view of rapidly changing conditions and
            generally slow implementation, TA projects should be kept as
            small and focussed as possible to avoid long implementation
            periods; and (iv) agreement should be reached with the
            government that procurement and recruitment steps should be
            completed during the 9-12 months while effectiveness is pending.

18151683.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen Arab Republic - Technical Assistance
            To the Central Planning Organization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Technical Assistance Project,
            complementing proposed but separate assistance from the
            Kuwait Fund, would strengthen the capabilities of the
            Central Planning Organization. It would achieve this by
            national economic planning and public investment
            programming, project evaluation and monitoring as well as
            developing and maintaining a national data bank. More
            specifically, it would: (a) provide on-the-job and overseas
            training for selected staff in key General Departments of
            CPO; (b) ensure greater coordination and complementarity
            between the General Departments, and between the CPO and
            other ministries/agencies. It would; (c) introduce improved
            procedures in economic planning and investment programming,
            project processing and cost control, and in reviewing
            contract documentation, management of technical assistance
            as well as improved procurement practices. Finally, the
            project would; (d) ensure a well-managed and organized
            central data processing capability in YAR. The project would
            finance about 13 staff-years of specialists' services
            and about 27 staff-years of overseas fellowship training;
            English language training, mainly in-country, for about 16
            CPO staff; and office and data processing equipment.
